Name: Dungeons & Dragons Dice Masters: Tomb of Annihilation
Description:
Dungeons & Dragons Dice Masters is a game that utilizes WizKids Games' proprietary Dice Building Game platform in which two players take the role of warlords, collect and assemble their "party" of adventurer dice and battle in head-to-head gameplay.  Each turn, players roll the dice to see what resources they have available, buy dice, send their party members into the field, and then strike at the enemy warlord. There are multiple cards available for each type of die so players get to choose which one  to use. This lets players specialize dice to suit play style.

The name and theme of the new expansion set will be the Tomb of Annihilation, set in the Forgotten Realms.  This set will offer new adventures, monsters, and spells for the game, as well as a new “Draft Pack” format, designed for tournament play.

Each Draft Pack will include 2 Basic Action cards, 12 Character or Action cards, 24 dice that match the 12 cards, and a rules insert.  All components can be used with other Dungeons & Dragons Dice Masters sets, but the sets have been designed for better use in draft-based games. Any Dice Masters Starter Set will be required to play (for starting NPC dice and Basic Action color indicator cards and dice).

The Dungeons & Dragons Dice Masters: Tomb of Annihilation will be sold in countertop displays.  Each display includes eight Draft Packs.

Name: Fuji Flush: ? Promo Card
Description:
The ? card is mixed in with all other cards at the start of the game. It counts as a wild and always takes on the lowest value of any card played by other players. Thus, this card can change its value several times before you discard it from play (either because you pushed the card through or because it is flushed down the drain by other players).

Included in every copy of Get The Cheese! from Stronghold Games.

Name: Holmes & Watson 1890-1914: Adventures in the London Fog
Description:
Description from the designer:

In Holmes & Watson 1890-1914: Adventures in the London Fog, players will roll dice and take actions so that they may solve the various mysteries of Victorian London. This roll and write adventure takes place all over the map of London, but be careful, Moriarty lurks around every corner.

On your turn, you will draft dice, use the actions of those dice, and navigate your way around the foggy streets to collect the needed evidence to solve the mysteries. If you cant move forward in your investigations, you lose.

Who will be the best investigator? Who will be thwarted by the schemes of Moriarty? Who will best Sherlock in a match of wits?

This game was entered into the 2017 Gencant Roll & Write Design Contest and received and Honorable Mention from the Judges.

Name: The Spanish Civil War
Description:
The Spanish Civil War is an Axis & Allies variant that takes place in Spain from 1936 - 1939.

It is in the form of a booklet and comes with:
Two 11" by 17" game maps
One 12 page rule book
One sheet of cut out counters

In addition to this game, you will need a set of plastic military figures to represent the game units and at least on ten sided die.
Families: Series: Obscure Wars Series (Guild of Blades)

Name: Black Market Bonanza
Description:
We’ve all heard stories of the great heroes and legends that span the worlds of fantasy, raiding dungeons, toppling strongholds, and slaying malicious monsters. We’ve all sat and listened to the tales of evil warlords and sorcerers raising armies and rancorous beasts to do their biddings. Now’s your chance to be the very source of all these stories! Jump behind the seller’s table. Rife through all the alchemical, magical, and sharp bits and goodies that make up the very foundation of the worlds of fantasy! And match them all up with the tricky characters that are willing to buy ‘em for your good ole fashion gold!

Black Market Bonanza is a living card game where Players select their special Seller Character Card and draw their own Seller's Table worth of Contraband Items to sell to Customers for precious gold coin counters. In the Contraband Deck, Players will find unique Contraband Items, some with special abilities, and tricky Sleight Of Hand Cards that be used for your own benefit or at the expense of your opponents! In the Market Deck, Players will draw the coveted Customer Encounters, the fun and random Market Events, or the dreaded Guard Encounter Cards! Beware of being thrown into Lockdown! Can't play the game much if you're stuck in a cell! All things in the Market Deck depend on your Seller's Skill Checks and lucky dice rolls, so be sure to choose your Seller wisely!

Your ultimate goal is to be the first Player to get to 10 Gold! So get those coins clanking into stacks, get all your items sold, and be the first to take control in Black Market Bonanza!

Name: Fools and Prospectors
Description:
A worker placement/set collection card game about mining gold during the American Gold Rush.

Put your miners to work in the gold mines. Get as much gold as possible, but watch out – make sure you aren’t wasting time collecting Fool’s Gold! Pay to check the quality of gold in the mines, and call out your opponent for trying to pay with Fool’s Gold or just plain rocks. Collect the highest values of gold by the end of the game to win.

Name: Finansije za kasnije
Description:
Finansije za kasnije ("Finance for Old Days") is a game about different financial products and how to use them. Players start with a birth and childhood, after that they have to decide would they work or study. On the half of the game they form family, and at last work for better carrier. They have different financial products, cash credits, home credits, savings, private pension fund and etc. Goal is to collect as much money for retirement. 
Game is not for sale, but for education purpose, my firm is arranging turners around the country in middle schools to teach pupils how to save money.

Name: Guilds of London: The Secret Guild of Guildsmen
Description: Promo card included in The Cousins' War. Acts as another guild.

Name: Savvy
Description:
How Savvy are you?

Starting with a random card between 1 and 36, players have to decide whether the next card drawn will be higher or lower to accumulate points... but this is no game of luck!

Each time you choose correctly, you accumulate a point in the 'holding area', and have the chance to choose higher or lower again from the new number, and get another point each time you guess correctly. BUT... guess incorrectly and lose all the points from that turn! The only way to keep your points is to elect to stop, at which point the next player continues from the current number.

Extra care is needed on the first guess of each of your turns too! You can elect to guess and start earning more points, but get your first guess wrong and you will lose half of all the points you have in your 'bank'!!!  Or, if its too risky, pass straight away to the next player, but this will cost you one point from your bank. If you've nothing in your bank, you must call!

Players on low points at the start of their turn, get another go if they get their first call wrong.

Counters mark which cards have already been drawn on a simple mat, so while this is a brilliant game of risk for anyone to play, it's also perfect for developing numerical and probability skills with children of all ages!

For 2-6 players, aged 8 and upwards, and a playing time of 10-40 minutes. The longer time scale relates to six players, the banter, and the liquid refreshment at hand.

More info and game session videos are available on the website at https://savvygames.co.uk

Name: SHAEF
Description:
SHAEF is a two-player WW2 card-driven wargame covering the ten months following D-Day in Western Europe.

One player takes the role of SHAEF – Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force commanded by US General Dwight D. Eisenhower. The Allied player’s goal is to control at least two of four key locations in Germany before the end of March 1945.  The Axis player seeks to frustrate these plans, but can win an instant victory if he can repel the Overlord invasion.

The historical armies and corps that fought in the campaign are represented by stand-up counters moving on the map. Smaller forces, plus combat support and special tactics, are handled by beautiful cards.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Safe House
Description:
Description from the publisher:

Dusk is falling. Wind is howling. Will you survive the night? It’s possible, if only you can make it to the Safe House. Grab your friends and dash across the neighborhood. Duck in and out of rundown houses, hiding as best as you can. The house at the end of the street is almost in sight. You can make it, just keep running. You can make it. Just. Keep. Running.

In Safe House, players are attempting to cooperatively save survivors. It’s a real time game that demands good teamwork and great communication. It’s frantic fun for all participants.

Name: Zombicide: Green Horde – Friends and Foes
Description:
Zombicide: Friends and Foes is an expansion for Zombicide: Green Horde. On the "Friends" side, it includes new Survivors and weapons to equip them, but also faithful Familiars to aid them in their quests. On the "Foes" side, the expansion contains challenging Tainted Walkers and Abomination, from which you'll want to keep your distance, 5 new treacherous tiles, and 10 new deadly Quests!

The full contents of the Zombicide: Friends and Foes expansion are:

4 Survivor figures and ID cards
6 Familiar figures
18 Tainted Walker figures
1 Tainted Abomination figure
5 double-sided tiles
17 Equipment cards
14 Zombie cards
Rulebook with 10 new Quests

Name: Yard of the Month
Description:
Version 2.0 coming 2023-2024.

In the pristine little neighborhood of Gnome Crossing, the competition for the highly coveted award of “Yard of the Month” is fierce. The residents will stop at nothing to win, including sabotage. While some gnomes will beautify and protect a garden, some gnomes will curse it, resulting in quite the eye sore.

Will you be the first to fill your garden with 10 flowers and be crowned “Yard of the Month,” or will you be the laughing stock of the neighborhood.

Yard of the Month is a family-friendly card game for 2 - 6 players. In the game, each player (neighbor) is competing to have the best flower garden. You have access to resources to either help or hinder a garden, including the garden gnomes Gnick and Gnack. While Gnick will keep your garden safe, Gnack's goal is to curse it, but that isn't anything a hammer can't handle.

Name: Go Go Dragons!
Description:
Go Go Dragons! is a dragon racing gaming designed to encourage participation and social interaction, promote observation and turn taking and introduce probability and chance.

In Go Go Dragons 2-4 players select a coloured dragon and take it in turns flipping over randomised coloured discs. When a disc is revealed the dragon matching the colour of the disc is moved forward one space. Once the dragon in last place reaches the discs on the board the disc is turned over and the matching coloured dragon is moved back one space

The winner is the first dragon to cross the finish line.

Name: Blue Mongolia
Description:
Blue Mongolia is a Monopoly reimplementation with a Mongolian theme and a trivia component.

Players move around a circular board buying and selling cultural elements of Mongolia (from the Gobi desert to the Mongolian costumes to the State play of Mongolia). When a player lands on an "About Mongolia" space, they must answer a trivia question, earning money if they answer correctly and losing money if they answer incorrectly.

Name: Deck Around
Description:
You pick a random slang term from the deck and everyone writes a made up but convincing definition for the word and anonymously hands it in.

One person reads all the definitions aloud, including the actual definition of the word, which is randomly mixed in.

Everyone guesses which definition is the real one and get points if they do. They usually fall for someone else's bullshit definition -- which earns its author a point.

Differences to regular balderdash would be more of a party-game for the adult crowd, adult-material.

Name: Flip Challenge
Description: Grab a plastic bottle (bottle not included. Additional purchase required) and start flipping with the Flip Challenge game! The game rules are simple – ace the Flip Challenges to earn points. First player to 10 points wins! Kids can practice the 34-included trick shot challenge cards solo or compete with friends! Game includes four different sized round targets and 34 bottle-shaped cards, each showing a challenge for the bottle flip. Challenges are grouped by category: some use the targets, some are physical challenges, and 6 cards challenge players to create their own trick shot. Each player has 5 chances to complete a challenge. So, grab a lucky water bottle, and go for the perfect flip!

Name: Sorcerers
Description:
A card game for 2 players based on the movie “Sorcerers Apprentice”. One player is the good Merlinians. The other is the evil Morganians.

Players share a common deck containing cards of seven types: 
Merlinian Sorcerers, Morganian Sorcerers, Spells, Amplifiers, Objects, Events and Defence.  Most cards have a power rating which is used during the duel (combat) phase.

The Merlinian player starts with Balthazar in play and the Grimhold which is equipped to Balthazar. The Morganian player starts with Horvath in play.

Both players draw 5 cards.

Each turn has 6 Phases:

1.  Lore Phase
-   Both players draw 2 cards from the deck.

2.  Recruit Phase
-   You may put one sorcerer into play from your hand and any number of objects. Sorcerers may give their objects to each other (max 3 objects per sorcerer). Excess objects are discarded. 
-   The Merlinian player may only recruit Merlinian Sorcerers. 
-   The Morganian player may only recruit Morganian Sorcerers.

3.  Event Phase
-   Starting with the Merlinian player, players may take turns discarding cards with event abilities to activate and immediately resolve those abilities.

4.  Encounter Phase
-   Each player randomly picks one of their sorcerers to undertake a duel.

5.  Duel Phase
-   The two Sorcerers who have encountered each other will now fight as follows.
-   Each player will make an attack combo which are then revealed simultaneously. For their attack combo each player may play one spell, one event and up to 3 amplifiers
-   Derive a power total for each sorcerer = the sorcerer’s power + equipped objects + spell + played event + amplifiers.
-   Each player may play up to one defence card. These will cause certain opposing cards to be discarded, thus changing the power totals. 
-   The sorcerer with the higher power total is the combat winner. The losing sorcerer is discarded.
-   The combat Loser may play a protection spell. This prevents the losing sorcerer from being discarded and his objects from being stolen.
-   The winner takes the losing Sorcerers objects AND looks at his opponents hand AND then steals one target card from his opponents hand.

6.  End Phase
-   Max hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards. 
-   Check for Victory Conditions. Record Time Markers.

The Merlinian player has 2 ways to win: 
1.  Destroy Morgana: Defeat her by 7 or more power in a Combat. 
2.  Prime Merlinian Succession: Keep Dave Stutler in play for 7 consecutive turns.

The Morganian player has 1 way to win: 
Cast the Rising Spell: Keep Morgana in play for 5 consecutive turns.

Both players may win by the following method: 
Army of Sorcerers: Have 6 more sorcerers in play than your opponent in the end phase.

Name: Spanish Saint Augustine
Description:
A card game for 2-4 players based on survival and accomplishment in the Florida City of St. Augustine.

St. Augustine was founded in 1565 by Pedro Menendez. It is the oldest, continuously inhabited European settlement in North America. For the first 200 years of its existence, it was controlled by Spain. The town itself was always very small and poor, but it held an important strategic position. It helped defend the treasure fleets on their way back to Spain by preventing the English and French from building their own settlements along the Gulf stream.

In this game players actively recruit townsfolk, earn gold, gain military glory, and build structures while being mercilessly subjected to hurricanes, raids, disease, and hostile indians.

Each turn is equal to about a decade. The game ends after 20 turns, at which point, historically, the British take control of the city.

Each Player gets a player mat which is divided up into 7 boxes: Government, Churches, Forts, Population, Gold, Glory and Victory Points. Tokens are placed in the boxes on player mats to keep track of each players score in that category. Each player starts with 7 population, 5 gold, and 3 glory.

There are 2 Common Decks: 
1.  The Event Deck - one random event occurs each turn. 
2.  The Action Deck which comprises four suits:
-   Economic (Types: Industry, Agriculture, Trade)
-   Military (Types: Fight the French, Fight the English, Control) 
-   Population (Types: Indians, Blacks, Europeans)
-   Buildings (Types: Government, Churches, Forts)
Each suit has 3 types of card with 4 cards for each type. In addition the deck has 4 leader (wild) cards.

Each turn is divided into 7 Phases:

1.  Draw Phase
-   Each Player fills their hand to 10 action cards.

2.  Trade Phase
-   Players may trade action cards with each other and may also trade tokens on their player mats.

3.  Meld Phase
-   Players may make melds. A meld consists of 1-4 cards of the same type. One card in a meld may be a leader. One card in a meld earns 1 token. Two cards in a meld earns 3 tokens. Three cards in a meld earns 6 tokens. Four cards in a meld earns 10 tokens. 
-   You can make a max of 4 melds, one from each suit. 
-   Tokens earned go into the relevant box on the player’s mat. (e.g. tokens from a population meld go into the population box, tokens from a military meld go into the glory box).

4.  Building Phase
-   Buildings provide bonus resources. Tokens are awarded for having the highest and second highest church, government and fort scores.

5.  Event Phase
 -  Flip over the top card of the event deck. The event is resolved immediately and affects all players.

6.  Score Phase
-   Players gain Victory Points (VP) in based on their population, gold and glory scores.

7.  End Phase
-   Players may discard their action hands down to zero cards.
-   Each player loses one half his gold rounding down. 
-   Each player loses all his Glory.

The game ends after 20 turns.  The player with the most VP at the end of the game wins.

Name: The Roots of Magic
Description:
The Roots of Magic is a tabletop miniatures game of duels between competing wizards in fantasy world. Players activate their wizards to perform mundane actions such as movement as well as casting spells and using other special abilities. The goal of the game varies depending on the scenario chosen and there might be multiple paths to victory.

The game can be played with a single wizard per player or the players may decide to use additional models such as apprentices and animal companions for a larger game. Individual scenarios may also add neutral monsters to the game.

The game rules are published online and the models are sold individually. Each model has their own card listing their various abilities. Players may add also tabletop terrain to the game from their collection.

Name: Arkham Horror: The Card Game – Echoes of the Past: Mythos Pack
Description:
Description from the publisher:

Echoes of the Past is the first Mythos Pack in The Path to Carcosa cycle for Arkham Horror: The Card Game.

The King in Yellow has come to Arkham, you caught the performance, and now you find yourself drawn into the maddening web of powerful forces and sinister event that seems to surround the mysterious play. So how do you proceed? Where do you continue your investigations? How you do hold onto the tattered threads of your limited sanity? If there are ties between the play and Arkham, there's one place where you might uncover them—the Arkham Historical Society, a landmark building that holds age-old secrets even its curator doesn’t know…

Even as it introduces a new scenario through which you can explore the Society’s hidden secrets—and the many terrors with which they are associated—Echoes of the Past introduces a wealth of player cards driven by two major themes that allow you to refine your investigator’s practiced Talent and Composure.
Families: Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: Arkham Horror – The Card Game
Game: Arkham Horror TCG – The Path to Carcosa
Series: Arkham Horror Files (Fantasy Flight Games)

Name: ASL: Journal – Issue Twelve
Description:
ASL JOURNAL 12 is a 40-page magazine and expansion for Advanced Squad Leader and features nine articles, the latest Q&A/errata, and 12 new scenarios printed on cardstock. Also included is a corrected scenario card for scenario 181 Gavin Take from the recent YANKS, which was missing its red text and is being replaced here.

JOURNAL 12 includes the following articles:


    The Umpire's view - Executive editors comment on this issue and coming games.
    A Dose of Antifreeze - Peter Struijf helps guide you through the decision matrix of how to defeat enemy vehicles using bypass "freeze". 
    ASL Crossfire: AP119 Konev Cross John Slotwinski and Phil Palmer discuss their playing of this Action Pack 12 scenario.
    Advanced Nuggets - Paul Sidhu brings light to some obscure and easily-overlooked rules.
    "Ghost Killers" - Andy Hershey recounts the history of the Korean Marine Corps, featured in the upcoming Korean War ASL module FORGOTTEN WAR which Andy helped design.
    Out With The Old... - Chas Argent looks at how old counter art from the Avalon Hill days is being updated for new MMP edition core modules.
    MOSSMOUSE! - Paul Sidhu is back and explains how the "Principles of War" as taught by the United States Army can be applied to your ASL play.
    Single-Hex Fire Groupology - Ken Dunn & J.R. Tracy de-mystify the Defensive First/Final Fire options available to units stacked together in the same Location.
    Debriefing This issue's errata updates.
    Scenario Analysis: AP71 Head In The Noose - Matt Shostak brings his magic analytical eye to this Action Pack 7 scenario.
    Recon: Flames in Hatten - Chas Argent previews Andrew Rogers's upcoming HASL on this German-vs-American HASL set during Operation NORDWIND in January 1945.


JOURNAL 12 also includes

12 new ASL scenarios:
J182 Belgian Blitzkrieg (German vs Belgian, 27 May 1940)
J183 A Real Barn Burner (French vs German, 31 May 1940)
J184 Dayan To Meet You (Australian vs Vichy, 8 June 1941)
J185 The Haunted Castle (German vs Russian, 22 June 1941)
J186 Castles On The Horizon (German vs British, 20 November 1941)
J187 In Deadly Combat (Russian vs German, 30 December 1941)
J188 Grab And Go (Russian vs German, 20 August 1943)
J189 Buckley's Block (Japanese vs U.S.M.C., 13 January 1944)
J190 Trial Run (Canadian vs German, 17 January 1944)
J191 Rebels Without A Pause (Slovak vs German, 5 September 1944)
J192 Taking Some Flak (Finn vs German, 28 October 1944)
J193 Raff's Rules (American vs German, 24 March 1945)

1 YANKS replacement scenario card (180-181)


2/8/17 JOURNAL 12 corrections:

• J192 Taking Some Flak: In the VC, last sentence, between "count" and "for" add "double".

• On page 31 of JOURNAL 12, the last sentence in the box of the "Single-Hex Firegroupology" article indicates that Final Fire in the DFPh might be available after having used Subsequent First Fire in the MPh. But that is not the case, since using SFF would mark a unit with a Final Fire counter, which precludes firing in the DFPh. We regret this error, which was introduced by the Editors in the editing process.

Name: Horse and Buggy Bonanza
Description: A set collection game using a board common to Monopoly and Bonanza style. Instead of buying and charging rent for spaces, the players compete to complete sets played on the board. The cards and matching spaces are based on Amish communities in a handful of US states.

Name: 6 qui prend!: L'extension vachement bien
Description:
Description from the publisher (translates):

10 extra cards that add a dose of cowardice and twists to your games of the famous 6 nimmt. With these new cards and two rule variants, the game will be even more spicy.

Name: Fábrica dos Sonhos
Description:
No matter their race, origin or desires, everyone has the right to be a child. Be it a knight or a magician, when we lie down to sleep the unconscious thoughts seem to transcend all realities. It is up to us, which is the connection between desire and thought, and the best children to all as persons. There are so many dreams created that are not so much that they have nicknamed our house of Factory of Dreams!

Take control of a mystical character such as Fairy, Unicorn, Gnome or Ente and build the dreams that citizens both crave in thoughts. Each character has a special ability that assists in their production and each citizen's card has a different dream to be built. During a match, it is necessary to send out items and emotions cards on the table according to what each citizen card is demanding.

How about joining that magnificent sword, a little courage, and giving the Warrior the glory of that very successful moment for him to kill the fearless Dragon ... in his dreams, of course! Can you be the best mystic in the game and be the employee of the month in the Factory of Dreams? Come and test your gifts, come and dream of us!

GAME SETUP: Each player stands at one end of the table. Your position is important because it determines whether a Desire card is valid for you or not according to the arrows of the cards. All players choose a character. Shuffle the Wishes deck (6 types) and reveal 16 cards in the center of the table placing four cards per row creating a 4x4 square. Shuffle the deck of Dreams and deal 2 cards to each player. The Dream cards are the template from which the player must form the same configuration with the cards arranged on the table.

GAMEPLAY: Fábrica dos Sonhos is divided into turns and actions. Each player on his turn performs the following mandatory actions:
World Change - You must remove a Wish Card from the table and place it in your hand, then replace that card with another one from the top of the Desire Deck or another one in your hand ( maximum of three cards in the hand). If you exceed the limit, before you pick up a new card, you must discard one of the cards in your hand.
Intercept - Choose between moving Desires Cards on the table or buying a new Dream card. The movement of Desires is simple. The movement points you have are equal to the number of players +1 . You can swap two orthogonally adjacent cards, or two cards diagonally that are on the corners of the 4x4 diagram. You can still rotate a letter anywhere. Each change of position or rotation counts as a point of movement.

GOAL: The objective of the players is to format the cards of the table according to the template of the cards of Dreams in their hands. The winner is the player who can achieve 3 dreams first.

COMPONENTS:
1 Rules Book
4 Character Sheet
20 Dreams Cards
38 Desires Cards

Name: Monarchs, Minions & Mayhem!
Description:
Game Overview:
Monarchs, Minions & Mayhem! is a Fantasy Themed Card-Driven Strategy Board Game. It has engaging gameplay that is extremely fun to play, well-balanced with innovative and unique game mechanics that will provide endless hours of entertainment with family & friends.

Number of Players: 3-8 (2-Player Variant Rules Included)
Or 3-4 (2-Player Teams)
Ages: 14+
Playing Time: 30+ Minutes
Game Components: Rulebook, 18”x18” Game Board, 108 Custom Playing Cards (poker size 2.5”x3.5”), (9) Gemstones & (1) 12-sided Dice.

Game Sets-Up in 5 minutes or less.
Simple to follow Rules & Game Play.
Replay-ability is virtually limitless. 
No two games will ever be the same.

 
Object of the Game:
Winning a round: The first player that has Zero (0) cards in their playing hand at the start of their next turn wins the round and gains 1 Gemstone.

Winning the game: After 3 rounds (Short Campaign), 6 rounds (Standard Campaign) or 9 rounds (Long Campaign) of play the player or team with the lowest casualty point score determined during the End Game Tally of the game (total casualty points minus Gemstone Point Bonus), Wins!

Setup & Dealer:
Players determine which campaign mode shall be played: Short Campaign (3 rounds), Standard Campaign (6 rounds) or Long Campaign (9 rounds). Players may opt unanimously at the end of a short or standard campaign to continue the game to the next campaign level if desired. 
 
Dealer: Either roll high (d12) or If playing a series of games, the winner of the last game is the dealer for initial set-up and the first round of play. The dealer in rounds 2 thru 9 changes to the player with the lowest total casualty points (score). Shuffle the 108 custom playing card deck and deals 1 card face down on each one of the 12 Battlefield Events.
 
Each player is then dealt 7 cards. The unused cards are placed face down as the Draw Deck and the top card is flipped face up to form the Battlefield.

Gameplay:
To start a round, the dealer shuffles the cards in the Draw Deck, Battlefield, Battlefield Event Wildcard and the Discard pile. Seven cards are then dealt out to each player from the Draw Deck, and the top card is flipped face up to form the battlefield. On the first round either roll high (d12) or if playing a series of games, the player with the highest score in the previous game flips over any one of the 12 face down cards in the Battlefield Event Area that is the Battlefield Event Wildcard that is in play (Revealed!) for the current round.

On rounds 2 thru 9 the player that “Won” the previous round and gained the Crown Jewel flips over any one of the remaining face down cards in the Battlefield Event Area, and places it in the area noted on the game board as the “Battlefield Event Wildcard”. 
 
Order of play begins with the person to the left of the dealer and proceeds in the direction determined by the card played on top of the existing card in the Battlefield.


     - If the Played card is lower rank = Play Direction Reversed to Counter Clockwise (Right).
     - Played card is higher rank = Play Direction Advances Clockwise (Left).
     - Played card is of equal rank (Stalemate) = player chooses direction of play left or right. 


If the Draw Deck is depleted, the battlefield (except the top card) is shuffled and becomes the new Draw Deck. Cards in the discard pile may only be shuffled into the Draw Deck at the beginning of each new round.

Turn Sequence: “Order of Play”
1.   Royal Decree Phase:  Player may choose to play a Monarch Card using the card’s Royal Decree.  The Royal Decree invokes any one Revealed Battlefield Event that the player chooses; if the Monarch card is played in this manner it is placed in the Discard pile and removed from play for the remainder of the round. There is no limit to the number of Monarch Cards that can be played during the players Royal Decree Phase using the Monarch Royal Decree. Regardless of whether or not a player plays a Monarch Card during the Royal Decree Phase, the player proceeds to the Battlefield Play Phase or Draw Phase of their turn.

2.  Battlefield Play Phase:  The player has several options to choose from, if available.


     - The player is not required to play a playable card in their playing hand if he/she chooses not to.



     - The player may play an Emissary or Scales of Justice card from their hand on top of any card in the Battlefield. Automatically changes faction currently in play to the faction type of the Emissary card. Continue on to the Battlefield Result Phase: The outcome of the battle is a Stalemate. After the faction change effect is resolved the rank value Emissary card is zero (0) for the next players turn.



     - The player may play a Monarch card as a Faction card from their hand on top of the card in the Battlefield. If the Monarch card either matches the faction or rank of the card in the Battlefield, continue on to the Battlefield Result Phase.



     - The player may play a Minion card as a Faction card from their hand on top of the card in the Battlefield. If the Minion card either matches the faction or rank of the card in the Battlefield, continue on to the Battlefield Result Phase.



     - The player may play a Minion card that matches the Rank of the Battlefield Event Wildcard that invokes any one of the Revealed! Battlefield Event that the player chooses. Resolve the Battlefield Event, and continue on to the Battlefield Result Phase.


3.  Draw Phase:  If the player was unable to play a card or chose not to play a card onto the Battlefield during the Battlefield Play Phase, they must draw a card from the Draw Deck.


     - If the card drawn by the player can be played as specified in sequential order of the preceding Royal Decree Phase or Battlefield Play Phase, the player may opt to do so.



     - The player is not required to play the drawn card even if it is a playable card.


4.  Pass Phase:  (end of players turn) If the player does not or cannot play a card onto the Battlefield, the player passes and play moves on to the next left (clockwise) player.

5.  Battlefield Result Phase:  (end of players turn) If the player has played a card on to the Battlefield, the Battlefield Result is determined by the card played on top of the existing card in the Battlefield.


     - Played card is lower rank = Play Direction Reversed to Counter Clockwise (Right).
     - Played card is higher rank = Play Direction Advances Clockwise (Left).
     - Played card is of equal rank (Stalemate) = player choses direction of play left or right.

Name: My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic – The Cooperative Adventure Game
Description:
Players take on the roll of the mane six ponies from the animated series and work together to prepare for a confrontation with one of the series villains. If the ponies have made enough progress, they can thwart the villain.

Each turn the players move their ponies around the game board, which is a map of Ponyville and Equestria.  They then attempt to deal with plot issue cards by rolling dice; other ponies can help them by rolling additional dice.  Successfully dealing with the issue cards allows them to advance on their Element track.  When they advance far enough, they will gain their Element of Harmony.

Meanwhile, the villain is plotting.  The villain has a progress track which advances each turn and when new issue cards come into play.  Villain event cards will come into play as the track advances and which will cause problems for the ponies.  Once the villain track reached the final space, the confrontation begins.  Ponies then attempt to defeat the villain with a series of dice rolls.  Their success will depend largely on how many Elements of Harmony they have obtained during the game.

Each of the mane six ponies has her own special ability: Twilight Sparkle can advance Element tracks by doing research, Rarity can collect gems to help her resolve issues, Fluttershy is good with animals, Rainbow Dash's movement is faster than the others, Applejack is good at helping other ponies resolve their issues, and Pinkie Pie can help other ponies avoid setbacks.

Players can play stand-alone games or a campaign game made up of a series of games, with a different villain in each game.  The ponies can gain new abilities and even become alicorns as the campaign continues.

Name: Guardsman
Description:
This is a two-player game where one player controls the 32 Peasants and one player controls the Three Guardsmen.  The guardsmen control the castle ( 3 x 3 positions) and the peasants try to gain control of the castle.  They start in the four corners of the board (each corner has 8 positions.)

To play: Peasants move first and then each player moves alternately.  Peasants move one space at a time and never jump.  Guardsmen may move one space or may jump one peasant, removing it from play. Guardsmen must jump if possible or be removed from play.  Moves can go in any direction, following the lines on the board.  Once in castle, the peasant can not leave.  The guardsmen can move in and out at will.

Name: Energy Crisis
Description:
Peppermill's Energy Conservation Game

From Cover:
Q. Is there really an energy crisis?
A. Yes, we are using up our favorite non-renewable fossil fuels at a furious pace, but we can learn how to conserve and use solar energy for most of our energy needs.  That's what this game is all about.

From Instructions:
Energy Crisis is a fast moving, game of chance, strategy, and educational fun.  It will challenge adults and fascinate children.  It's a game the whole family will enjoy.

Game Play:
This is a role and move game where players are trying to insulate their house, convert to solar energy and conserve your energy units.  Use your energy units to pay your bills.  There are various spaces on the board where you buy solar collectors and insulation, collect energy, and pay bills.  Play continues until one player acquires 10 solar collectors or until all other players run out of energy units.

Name: Trivial Pursuit: The Walking Dead
Description:
An epidemic of apocalyptic proportions has swept the globe with the bite-size edition of The Walking Dead™ Trivial Pursuit®. Featuring 600 questions that cover the characters and events included in the popular comic book series, even the most ardent fans will be challenged to fight for their survival. First person to collect six cards becomes the last survivor.

Contents:

100 cards feature 600 questions

Categories include: People, Locations, Events, Issue Numbers, The Dead and Wild Card
 1 Custom Die
 Wedge case card holder
 Instructions

Name: Underlords
Description:
Underlords is a 1-4 player fantasy game where players take on the role of the Underlords, hard done by masters of the dark who only want to make an innocent evil subterranean empire filled with minions and monsters. Alas these tranquil utopias find no peace as pesky adventurers keep turning up at the door trying to steal everything and killing every minion in sight.

In Underlords players use tile placement to build a dungeon full of rooms and caves, into which minions and monsters are placed. Each turn the underlord push their luck by sending monsters out to raid villages, towns or cities to gather plunder which is used to recruit minions and build the dungeon.

Each turn one hero arrives at the dungeon seeking treasure. Depending on how hard the Underlord raided, this could be a plucky peasant or a gristle nemesis of evil. The hero travels through the dungeon in a tower defence fashion being battled on the way by the dungeons defenders.

The game is won by the player who accrues the most magic items from fallen hero's by the end of the game.

Name: Bank Elhaz
Description:
This is a Sudanese version of Monopoly.

"With regards from The Modern Bank of Luck
The only agent in Sudan"

It is completely in Arabic, but I've had most of it translated.  The mechanics are the same, however with slightly different rule variations.  Properties focus on Arabic cities in Northern Africa and the Middle East including Khartoum, Aleppo, Benghazi and Baghdad.  You can purchase garages, restrooms or markets.

Description from the rules translated into English:
"The Bank of Luck game is one of the best games that guarantees players a good time and makes people love honest trade in the sale and purchase of cities, garages, restrooms, etc.  It is one of the most famous games played by 2 to 6 players and preferably more than 2 players."

Name: Unlock!: Mystery Adventures
Description:
Unlock! is a cooperative card game inspired by escape rooms that uses a simple system which allows you to search scenes, combine objects, and solve riddles. Play Unlock! to embark on great adventures, while seated at a table using only cards and a companion app that can provide clues, check codes, monitor time remaining, etc.

Unlock! Mystery Adventures features three "escape room" scenarios that you can play on your tabletop:


    The House on the Hill: What's going on in this run-down manor? Explore the sinister pieces and foil the curse that haunts this desolate place. Designed by Fabrice Mazza, illustrated by Pierre Santamaria.



    The Nautilus' Traps: Attacked by a sea monster during a dive, you seek shelter by opening a hatch in an old submarine. Find a way back to the surface! Designed by Arnaud Ladagnous, illustrated by Florian de Gesincourt.



    The Tonipal's Treasure: Captain Smith hid his treasure on Tonipal Island. Unravel the mystery before Johnson, another treasure hunter, beats you to it! Designed by Billy Stevenson & Sebastien Pauchon, illustrated by Sergo.


Note: Unlock! requires a free application to be downloaded from the App Store or Google Play. Once downloaded, an internet connection is not required during game play.

Name: WarQuest: 5th Player Expansion and Experienced Units
Description: WarQuest: 5th Player Expansion and Experienced Units includes everything you need to play WarQuest with more people as well as an experienced unit system and an imperial guard die for each faction! The rules are a compendium for quick reference to get you in the action quicker, too!

Name: Tentacle Bento: Maid Service
Description:
Metal miniature and Expansion Card for Tentacle Bento

Card Details
Discard up to three cards and then draw an equal number of cards from the school pile.

Name: Tentacle Bento: Teacher's Helper
Description:
Metal miniature and Expansion Card for Tentacle Bento

Card Details
Target opponent draws two cards from the school pile.

Name: Tentacle Bento: Detention
Description:
Metal miniature and Expansion Card for Tentacle Bento

Card Details
Shuffle the entire field back into the pile.

Name: Tentacle Bento: Kendo Club
Description:
Metal miniature and Expansion Card for Tentacle Bento

Card Details
Remove any one sporty student from an opponent's noble capture and place it in the field.

Name: Mystic Vale: Shard Eater
Description:
Sunshards are crystals that absorb the power of the sun and constantly glow with  golden light; the brighter a sunshard glows the more potent its power source is. Shard Eaters are elementals with an appetite for raw power. Sunshards are a delicacy to the Eaters, and each shard consumed allows them directly to harness its pure energy. The Eaters then use the imbued light of the sunshards to repel the corrupting curse that is spreading throughout the Valley of Life.

The Shard Eater advancement has the lowest mana cost for a growth symbol in the game, allowing you to add a growth to your deck as early as the first turn. However, this early power comes with a longterm price of lowering your mana during future turns while it’s in your field. Placing a Shard Eater advancement in a card with a Cursed Land will neutralize its decay symbol, allowing you to sow your field with more cards.

The promo pack includes 3 Shard Eater advancements (one advancement for the top, middle, and bottom slots). This allows players to craft cards with Shard Eater for any slot position.

Name: Blank Marry Kill: #?&! Marry Kill
Description:
Description from the publisher:

#?&! Marry Kill is an expansion to Blank Marry Kill, and will add all kinds of explicit R-rated references to your decisions. We're not going to lie; there's some bad stuff in here. So if you want to make your Blank Marry Kill decisions even more horrible, this is the deck for you.

Name: Blank Marry Kill: Geek Marry Kill
Description:
Description from the publisher:

Geek Marry Kill is an expansion to Blank Marry Kill, and will add all kinds of comic book, video game, and pop culture references to your decisions. This is your chance to finally MARRY LINK, BE SLOWLY DIGESTED IN A SARLAC PIT WITH BRIENNE, and KILL IKEA MONKEY. Hey, these decisions aren't supposed to be easy.

Name: Rise War of the Nightwalkers
Description:
Vampires and Werewolves go on with their constant war , in a less evident and destructive way, conducting a kind of cold war, with underground fights. But this war is like a circle without end, rivers of blood runs through the city streets, making death something like a daily occurrence.

Rise is a collectable card game that consist of a duel between two teams of Leader. The purpose of the game is to reduce to zero the number of the point life of the opposite player. There isn’t a standard set of cards. Each player starts the duel with a deck of cards that he has previously assembled by selecting between all the game cards.

Name: Deep Space D-6: The Endless
Description:
To defeat this new threat you'll have to perform overkill effects or be prepared to be overwhelmed by rapidly deploying enemy fleets. The Endless feed off each other and the more of them on the board, the more dangerous they become. Lucky for you, we've got ship upgrades available to help you overcome this radical new threat.


     54 new cards including external threats, internal threats, ship upgrades, and a new final encounter.
     Replacement Ouroboros cards to bring the 1st edition inline with the 2nd printing.


Note: You do not mix this new expansion with the base game cards. This new mini-expansion plays on its own but requires the base game. However, the upgrades can be used with the original threat deck. Fully compatible with all 4 ships. Yes, it fits in the base game box.

Name: Blood and Dust
Description:
Description from the designer:

Blood and Dust is a game of strategy and adventure enabling players to participate in fierce battles between armies of Medieval times. The game faithfully reenacts the harsh combat reality of this period - heavy cavalry charges breaking enemy lines, lethal salvoes of archers or brutal infantry melees. Players have to choose the right tactics making flank or rear attacks as well as organize their regiments in proper formations. It is also important to take advantage of the lay of the land and use special abilities of commanders and units.

The game can be played in three different game modes for 2 to 4 players: standalone Scenarios designed by the author, standalone Scenarios custom-build by the players and the Campaign. In the Blood and Dust Campaign, the players become captains of mercenary forces who sell their military services in a world full of dangers, intrigues and brutal battles. Your heroes start from commanding a small detachment of units, but as the Campaign progresses, they will muster additional units for their armies. They will improve skills and search for fresh recruits, while their soldiers will gain experience in uncountable skirmishes. For a sack full of gold they will accept commissions, helping the wealthy and the powerful attain even more influence. Alternatively, they will seek glory and money on their own.

Name: Would You Rather...? Kinda Clean Party Edition
Description:
Would You Rather…? Kinda Clean Party Edition is the game of crazy choices and demented dilemmas! Your goal is to figure out which dilemma the other players would rather do. There are two ways to play: Classic Dilemmas give you two outrageous options to choose from, and Fill-in-the-Blank Dilemmas have missing words that you provide. Once the group has revealed their choice, turn over your previously selected Voting Token to see if you matched. With over 1000 dilemmas to choose, Would You Rather…? Kinda Clean Party Edition is where outrageous choices are all part of the game.

FEATURES
Fill in the blank, you pick the words. Expect the unexpected.
A or B dilemma cards offer two different options to choose from.
Over 1000 dilemmas! Outrageous choices are all part of the game!

Name: Orphan Black: Clone Club
Description:
Description from the publisher:

Orphan Black: Clone Club is hidden information, matrix building, card laying game of DNA connections. Co-Designers Daryl Andrews (Outpost: Siberia) and Bryce Hunter has 2-5 players competing to control the genetic pool, all while hiding their genetic information from their fellow clones. Players will have to lay down cards in a unique connection building matrix, where not only will gene strands grow out, but each clone will have to lay gene cards on top of each other to build up. Grow out your preferred connections or block opposing clones from controlling the genetic sequence. When the matrix has been completed, the clone with the most Science Point tokens wins the game.

Name: Zombicide: Black Plague – Game Night Kit 1
Description:
Contains a 3-part mini-campaign and exclusive Bruce figures with dashboards.

Components:

1 Letter
1 Poster
1 Sticker
2 Rules Leaflets
14 Bruce Miniatures
14 Bruce dashboards
26 Custom Dice
84 Counter Bases (14 Base Counter Packs containing 1 each of Purple, Grey, Red, Brown, Beige, and Green Base Counters)

Name: Hut Alive Card Game
Description:
Player: 2-4 Players
Time: 10 mins (2 players) 20 mins(3-4 players)
Card deck: 52

SETTING GAME:

Shuffling and sharing cards:
A player shuffles and shares the card. Each player would get 10 cards.

BAITING

Each player selects and place 5 CARDS that would serve as BAITS for the fight. These cards are chosen based on the player's choice on elements such as high number, HUT colour etc).

HOW TO PLAY:

1. At their turns, players try to eliminate other player's BAIT by placing a higher number HUT (with the same colour) on the BAIT to be eliminated.

For instance, if a PLAYER has baits with number 9, 9, 8, 7, 8, an active player (player whose turn it is) who places a card with higher number of the same colour as the BAIT collects the BAIT and other cards on it if BAITS has been HEXED, DEFENDED or INVADED (see below).

HEX:

Players can use their turn to HEX any BAIT (either theirs or another players). They do so by placing ANOTHER HUT COLOUR with the same number as the BAIT to change the colour. This is a very important in the game strategy.

DEFEND:

Players can DEFEND their BAIT by placing another card with HIGHER NUMBER but MUST be the same HUT colour as their BAIT. This is a strategy for defence in the game.

INVADE:

ACTIVE PLAYER can weaken another players BAIT by INVADING. This is done when Active Player place a card with LOWER NUMBER on another player's BAIT but must be the same COLOUR. This makes the BAIT weaker and easier to eliminate at next run by any player.

WHEN GAME ENDS:

The game ends when any player has EXHAUSTED their FIVE BAITS.

HOW TO WIN???

THE PLAYER WITH THE HIGHEST NUMBER OF BAITS AT THE END OF THE GAME WINS.

In situations where there is a TIE, the players FIGHTS and the FIRST to lose a BAIT gets ELIMINATED TILL THEIR IS ONLY ONE PLAYER LEFT.

Name: Tiny Epic Defenders: The Dark War
Description:
Aughmoore is in ruins. The evil could not be contained and its darkness has spread to every region of the world. Shattering villages and infecting all forms of life. There has never been a more dire need for Heroes. Everyone who remains must rise up, must unite, and must risk everything to preserve what little spirit remains.

Tiny Epic Defenders The Dark War, an expansion to Tiny Epic Defenders, is the latest installment in Chronicles of Aughmoore. It introduces new Heroic characters like the Lionkin Charioteer and the Birdfolk Shadow Walker. It also introduces new Epic Foes, new Dire Enemies, and new Artifacts, but more importantly it introduces new and exciting features that keep players making difficult choices from the edge of their seats.

These new features include a Campaign Mode, with Enemy Generals, Skills that Heroes can learn, Advanced Regions and Caravans.

Caravans represent the shattered homes of villagers during this dark time and are spread across all the Regions. Players are faced with the additional challenge of rescuing these Caravans and escorting them safely to the Capital City before they are can defeat the Epic Foe.

Skills are useful abilities players can assign to their Heroes and require Experience Points to activate. Experience Points are now earned during play by making meaningful decisions that help the party reach their goals.

The Campaign Mode plays like an evolving gauntlet challenge, where players must play through the game multiple times facing Generals at the intervals instead of the regular Epic Foe. The different abilities players will have at their disposal, as well as the threats they face, are unique to each Campaign and evolve with the choices players make during each Campaign. If players can survive long enough, they will face an Epic Foe at the conclusion of the Campaign.

The Advanced Regions introduce new threats and also new abilities to aid the players in The Dark War. These new threats and abilities come in the way of 3D constructs like a giant Tree Heroes can hide in, a flying Manticore Heroes can ride, or mysterious Sandstorms! They play a big part of the evolving Campaign Mode. Each Advanced Region features a dark, harmful, side and a light, helpful, side. As player progress through the Campaign Mode, they will work to restore the dark regions to their helpful side. Making the right choices to restore these Regions and rescue the Caravans are critical to achieving victory in Campaign Mode.


For a deluxe edition of this expansion, see Tiny Epic Defenders: The Dark War â€“ Deluxe Edition

Name: Trump!
Description:
Trump! is a new take on traditional playing cards--adding special symbols to many cards, which alters game play of favorite card games like Cribbage, Go Fish, War, Hearts, and dozens of others.

Each card has a Trump administration official or staff member and includes additional information about the individual.

Officials can be crossed out if fired, resign, or are impeached, changing their value or giving them special abilities in many card games.

The game is one part update on classic card games, one part education, and one part resistance, Trump! should provide hours of fun and politicized entertainment!

Name: Aventuria: Heroes' Struggle
Description:
In the Bornland, in the north of Aventuria, in the Horasreich and even in the exotic Uthuria lead the way for the Heros of Aventuria there thy can solve criminal cases, to archive strange missions and to fight against terrifying monsters. They must trust on their wits and their stamina and, most important for a hero of Aventuria: the fellow mates.

Heroes Struggle is the third expansion for the Aventuria Card Game. This box contains six short adventures. Additionally, it introduces a new hero, Rovena, a catwitch.


German original Text:
Ins Bornland, nach Nordaventurien, ins Horasreich und selbst in das exotische Uthuria verschlägt es die Helden aus Aventurien, um spannende Kriminalfälle zu lösen, kuriose Aufträge zu erfüllen und gegen furchteinflößende Gegner anzutreten. Sie müssen sich dabei auf ihren Grips und ihr Durchhaltevermögen verlassen, sowie auf das Wichtigste, das ein Held von Aventurien auf seiner Seite hat: seine Kameraden.

Heldenreigen ist eine Abenteuererweiterung für Aventuria - Das Abenteuerkartenspiel. Es enthält sechs abwechslungsreiche Kurzabenteuer für Aventuria und eine neue Heldin: Rovena aus dem Überwals, eine Katzenhexe, die ihre Zauber und Fähigkeiten auf subtile Weise einsetzt, um ihre Gegner zu überwinden.
Families: Versions & Editions: Board Game Versions of Role-Playing Games

Name: Baseball Classics All-Time Greats Splits Edition
Description:
The Greatest MLB All-Time Teams

Our Baseball Classics All-Time Greats Game with 22 Major League Baseball franchise team sets of team charts with color-coded batting, fielding, bunting, stealing, base running, and pitching ratings.

National League
Houston Colt 45s-Astros, Boston/Milwaukee/Atlanta Braves, St. Louis Cardinals, Chicago Cubs, Brooklyn/Los Angeles Dodgers, New York/San Francisco Giants, New York Mets, Philadelphia Phillies, Pittsburgh Pirates, Cincinnati Reds, Montreal/Washington Expos-Nationals

American League
Los Angeles/California/Anaheim Angels, Philadelphia/Kansas City/Oakland Athletics, Cleveland Indians, Baltimore/St. Louis Browns, Boston Red Sox, Detroit Tigers, Kansas City Royals, Washington/Minnesota Senators-Twins, Chicago White Sox, New York Yankees, Washington/Texas Senators-Rangers

Name: Careless Heroes
Description:
Also nicknamed 'Fashion Fighters', and based on the popular Gaki no Tsukai series, this card game replicates one of their most famous challenges:  Can five heroes (or more!) transform into their super costumes while not caring to recall which hero they actually are?

You take on the role of 5 "Powered" Ranger style heroes in 5 unique colors: Red Ranger, Blue Ranger, Green Ranger, Gold Ranger, and Pink Ranger.  Yet, you are all careless, and always forget which ones you are. Also, NO table talking is allowed because you are also too proud to call each other to ask.

Your goal is to show up to the battle in a unique Ranger suit, matching no other Ranger's color.  Matching another ranger simply will not do, and you will refuse to fight and just go home.  It's embarrassing.

Basic rules: Players have 5 cards each in their starting hands: one card for each of the 5 costume colors (add more colored cards for more players than 5).  Choose a starting player (a lead Ranger) and everyone secretly picks a color costume to wear and puts that matching color card face down in front of them.  Starting with the leader and going clockwise, you will flip your card face up in front of you and yell "[Insert color you played] RANGER GO!".

If all the colors are different, you fight the threat and save the day.  If not, you take any non matching cards into your hand or discard any colors that matched another player (place the discarded card in front of you, face up, so everyone can see what color you lost).

You refuse to ever experience that humiliation again and throw the costume out.  If the same color card is lost by all players, the game is impossible to win, and you instantly lose.

Lastly, (this can be a variant or base rule, your choice) a Ranger will never show up in the same costume twice in a row, so for the following round you must pick a different color to play (eg., yellow, yellow, blue is not allowed, but yellow, blue, yellow is).  Players need to use deduction and pay attention to what costumes are out of play to come out on top!

Name: Love Means Nothing
Description:
Love Means Nothing is a real-time tennis game for exactly four players. Players volley back and forth, rapidly playing the correct defensive card that also says where that response shot is headed.

The game plays with standard tennis scoring, so you can play a single game up to a full match. With only a count of five Wimbledons to respond, screwing up is inevitable, so when your partner drops the ball, you'll quickly see that Love means nothing...

Name: Decksistentialism
Description: Decksistentialism is a social metagame that's played whenever something else is going on: at the bar, game night, conventions, whatever. Cards have triggers on them based around simple things like "someone drops something" or "someone uses their phone to settle an argument" as well as darkly funny existential statements related to that trigger like "You cling to what pieces you can, burdened by the knowledge of that which you can never hold onto." When someone sets off a trigger, they get passed the appropriate card. Players can choose how long to play for, and at the end, whoever has the fewest cards still loses (or wins if we're being pedantic). Tragic hilarity ensues.

Name: Decksistentialism: Game Night
Description:
Decksistentialism: Game Night consists of nine cards for Decksistentialism that are specifically focused around game nights. A player finishes in last place? It's okay. "Win or lose, you will still die and be forgotten."

You're still looking to end up with the fewest cards, but now you've got to watch out for what you're doing at game night, too.

Name: Decksistentialism: Conventions
Description:
Decksistentialism: Conventions consists of nine cards for the social metagame Decksistentialism, this time focused on convention play. Someone asks you to play a prototype? Pass them a card and let them know that "The only thing you will ever truly finish is living."

You're still looking to have the fewest cards at the end of the convention, but now there are even more things to look out for.

Name: You Fool
Description:
Circus Clowns pour out of their tiny clown car to form a small human pyramid — but one fool does not make it into the display, and is smacked in the face with a pie for the entertainment of all. Don't be that fool.

You Fool is a 3-4 player bluffing/negotiation game about making a human pyramid of clowns and trying not to be the only player not in the pyramid. In this highly social game, players secretly look at a movement card and try to direct the active player on how to use that card. Sometimes players will cooperate to make the pyramid together and other times they will straight up lie to secure their position.

Once the top three spaces of the pyramid are formed, the game ends. The player who is not on the pyramid loses the game and, naturally, gets a pie to the face.

Name: SimplyClever.Cards Addition 1
Description:
SimplyClever.Cards Addition 1 combines traditional playing cards with math flash cards. The deck has 52 cards in 4 colours numbered 0-12, and 4 jokers.

Each card is illustrated with an addition calculation (e.g. 0+0, 2+1 or 6+6) corresponding to the card value from 0 to 12.

One joker has a table showing which 4 cards match up for each value, in order to check the math when necessary. The remaining 3 jokers have mathematical operators +, - and = so you can make your own calculations using the cards.

Designed to function like a regular deck of cards (including traditional pips for suits and ranks), SimplyClever.Cards  Addition 1 allows you to play any regular card game you want to - but with a mathematical twist! Game examples: 500, Casino, Crazy Eights, Go Fish, Hearts, Memory, Old Maid, Slap Jack, Snap, UNO etc.

Name: SimplyClever.Cards Subtraction 1
Description:
SimplyClever.Cards Subtraction 1 combines traditional playing cards with math flash cards. The deck has 52 cards in 4 colours numbered 0-12, and 4 jokers.

Each card is illustrated with a subtraction calculation (e.g. 1-1, 3-2 or 15-3) corresponding to the card value from 0 to 12.

One joker has a table showing which 4 cards match up for each value, in order to check the math when necessary. The remaining 3 jokers have mathematical operators +, - and = so you can make your own calculations using the cards.

Designed to function like a regular deck of cards (including traditional pips for suits and ranks), SimplyClever.Cards  Subtraction 1 allows you to play any regular card game you want to - but with a mathematical twist! Game examples: 500, Casino, Crazy Eights, Go Fish, Hearts, Memory, Old Maid, Slap Jack, Snap, UNO etc.

Name: SimplyClever.Cards Multiplication 1
Description:
SimplyClever.Cards Multiplication 1 combines traditional playing cards with math flash cards. The deck has 52 cards in 4 colours numbered 0-12, and 4 jokers.

Each card is illustrated with a multiplication calculation (e.g. 0*1, 2*2 or 3*4) corresponding to the card value from 0 to 12.

One joker has a table showing which 4 cards match up for each value, in order to check the math when necessary. The remaining 3 jokers have mathematical operators +, - and = so you can make your own calculations using the cards.

Designed to function like a regular deck of cards (including traditional pips for suits and ranks), SimplyClever.Cards Multiplication 1 allows you to play any regular card game you want to - but with a mathematical twist! Game examples: 500, Casino, Crazy Eights, Go Fish, Hearts, Memory, Old Maid, Slap Jack, Snap, UNO etc.

Name: SimplyClever.Cards Division 1
Description:
SimplyClever.Cards Division 1 combines traditional playing cards with math flash cards. The deck has 52 cards in 4 colours numbered 0-12, and 4 jokers.

Each card is illustrated with a division calculation (e.g. 0:1, 3:3 or 48:4) corresponding to the card value from 0 to 12.

One joker has a table showing which 4 cards match up for each value, in order to check the math when necessary. The remaining 3 jokers have mathematical operators +, - and = so you can make your own calculations using the cards.

Designed to function like a regular deck of cards (including traditional pips for suits and ranks), SimplyClever.Cards Division 1 allows you to play any regular card game you want to - but with a mathematical twist! Game examples: 500, Casino, Crazy Eights, Go Fish, Hearts, Memory, Old Maid, Slap Jack, Snap, UNO etc.

Name: Twilight Sparkle's Secret Shipfic Folder: Tales of Ponyville University
Description:
Ponyville University is to be used with the Core Deck of TSSSF!

Twilight Sparkle (Equestria's most prolific and horrific fanfic author) has embarked on a quest to create the perfect YA stories! And who better to act as guinea pi- er… the stars of her tales, but the young ponies of Ponyville?

Join the narrative thread woven by Twilight through ridiculousness, adorableness and maybe even a little romantic horror as she tells…

The Tales of Ponyville University!

In order to help fulfill Twilight’s dream of writing the perfect fanfics, you take turns expanding the shipping grid, joining new ponies with “ship” (short for relation”ship”) cards.

TSSSF uses three decks of cards: Ponies, Ships and Goals. Players use Ship cards to pair different Ponies together on an expanding grid, earning VP for completing Goal cards for different combinations formed on the grid.

If you are the first to make one of Twilight’s narrative goals a reality, you earn points!

Name: Final Round Fighting Card Game
Description:
Final Round Fighting Card Game is a two-player card game which emulates Arcade Fighting Games of the 90s.

In Final Round Fighting Card Game, players play cards to simulate attacking and defending against their opponent as they attempt to deal damage to one-another, removing cards from their opponents deck as damage is done. The players deck is made up of cards, each of which represent a move the character they are playing as is able to perform. Cards lost from the deck through damage become a resource from which players draw.

As with Arcade Fighting Games, there are Basic Attacks (simple 1-button punches and kicks), Special Attacks (more complicated or specialized moves, frequently unique to a character), Basic Block and Special Blocks (Basic Block is reusable throughout the game, Special Blocks have an additional effect) and Ultimate moves (the big, flashy finishers).

Cards/Moves in Final Round Fighting Card Game are balanced by i. Attack Speed (how fast a card is), ii. Combo Speed (the maximum Attack Speed of the card to follow it in a Combo), iii. Damage (the number of cards your opponent loses from their deck when they're hit with the attack alone or in a Combo), and iv. Card Abilities.

Gameplay consists of playing cards defensively to your own High, Mid, and Low zones, or playing a card aggressively to Attack your opponent in one of their three zones (the zones are largely thematic, to represent the "spacing" aspect from fighting video games). Attacks are successful when they are faster than the card in the zone they were played to, with Blocks being an automatic success for the defending player, and ties being broken by revealing the top card of players' decks and using the Attack Speed of the revealed card. On successfully attacking the opponent, players have the ability to play additional cards, making a Combo, with each successive card in a Combo requiring having an Attack Speed which is equal to or less than the Combo Speed of the last card which was played. During a players turn, they have two Actions, in which they can play defensively to draw cards and reset their defenses, or to attack.

—description from the designer

Name: Escape: Zombie City – Queenie 4
Description: 1 new character and 2 new street tiles that can be used with Escape: Zombie City.

Name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple – Queenie 12: Slide
Description:
Queenie 12 for Escape. 2 new chambers and 1 new curse

Slide Chamber: When this chamber is discovered, the discovering player must place his adventurer immediately into this chamber. Once discovered, all players may enter the chamber through the stairway without needing to use any symbols. To enter the chamber through the other entrance, the player must roll the symbols shown on the tile as normal (in this case, 3 torch symbols).

Debris Chamber: In order to discover this chamber a player has to roll 2 adventurers as well as a key and a torch symbol.

Cyclops Curse: You must place one hand over one of your eyes and keep it there until this curse is lifted.

Name: Monopoly: Queen
Description: A re-themed version of Monopoly meant to evoke a feeling of touring as the band Queen.

Name: WTF  Did You Say?!?
Description:
Description from the publisher:

How it goes down.
Each player starts with 10 white cards in their hand. Whomever masturbated most recently is named the first ROC or Reader of Cards. After a thorough hand washing, this person draws and reads a red card out loud. Each player (not the reader) then passes their “funniest” white card face down to the ROC. Once all white cards are received the ROC reads each white card out loud in context of the red card.

The ROC chooses which card they believe to be “funniest” and gives the red card to the player that played that card. Play moves around in a circle until: abs are wrecked from laughing, someone passes out, or the majority pusses out. Person with the most red cards at the end of the game wins.

Name: Brew Ha Ha!
Description:
Brew Ha Ha is a beer-tasting game ...

Players draw 8 cards, sample a beer, then piece their cards together to create a description of what they taste.

The Brewmaster (judge) of each round gets to wield their almighty power to award 2 points:

1 point for their favorite description of the round
1 point for the description they deem most accurate

Name: OXO: The mandala card game
Description:
OXO is a card game with a wonderful mandala look. You can learn it in 5 minutes and you're ready to play.

In OXO, you have to form palindromes with the cards in your hand and in the table in order to get rid of your wealth counters and reach a new status of wisdom.

OXO is a fast, portable, family game. It comes with 2 different modes and can be player in solitaire.

Name: Above and Below: Desert Labyrinth and Underforest Encounter Book
Description:
Printed Desert Labyrinth and Underforest Encounter Book (36 pages) for base game. More stories and encounter events for the explore action.

You must have the Expanded Edition Cardboard Tokens to use the Desert Labyrinth and Underforest Encounter Book. The Above and Below: Expanded Edition Exclusives contains those and 81 Wooden Goods.

Name: Doro-Doko
Description: This is a deduction game happening in a honeycomb-shaped collective housing complex. Guess where the robber is hiding, using stolen goods as clues.

Name: Blood Bowl (2016 Edition): Skaven Team Booster
Description:
Skaven society is highly stratified and bound up in complex rituals, but on the Blood Bowl pitch, all barriers drop away as every player gives their all for their team’s complete and utter victory. The game has become very popular in all fields of Skaven life – the Skaven loving any opportunity for mindless violence. In fact, it has been very difficult to persuade them that there is any other purpose to the game once they are on the field, or even when they are just spectating in the stands! Some of the great all-time Player Death and Crowd Death records have occurred in games in which the Skaven have been on the pitch.

Expand, enhance, fill out and indeed boost your Skaven team with this booster pack! It contains 4 resin miniatures – 2 Gutter Runners, a Blitzer and a Thrower – each covered in detail and posed dynamically, with all the billowing cloaks, sinister hoods, sharpened teeth and ghastly claws you’d expect. the Blitzer is a particular standout: not content with his own natural claws, he’s added pointy things to nearly every surface of his body and armour he can…

These 4 resin miniatures come as 14 components, and are supplied with 4 32mm Blood Bowl bases.

Name: Unexpected Plots
Description: This is a party card game for 3-7 players (or teams). Players create film reviews, deforming the plot, hiding some elements of it or magnifying other aspects. The goal is to ruin the movies (series or books) you love or love to hate.

Name: Afterglow
Description:
Skirmish Warfare in the Far Future.

The rules for AFTRERGLOW (a 3 page pdf) were designed to allow people with a range of figures to vaporise each other into a satisfying afterglow.

Troop listings are provided for commonly available science fiction miniatures but are modifiable at the discretion of players.  Troop types have skill factors for close and ranged combat, armour, speed, courage, leadership, hit points. Troops also have a cost value.

Game sequence is as follows:


     Roll Command Points
         Each squad rolls 1D6 and modifies according to leadership.  Command points may be used to move a figure, snapfire at a new target during movement phase or reload a heavy weapon.
    
     Move Troops
         Figures are moved a fixed distance modified by a speed factor.
    
     Ranged Combat
         Roll combat dice for weapon type, add any ranged combat skill and situational modifiers.  Each score of six or more is a hit.  All natural rolls of 1 are misses.
    
     Close Combat
         Roll combat dice for weapon type and add close combat skill factor.  Each score of six or more is a hit.  All natural rolls of 1 are misses.  
         Targets roll a saving throw on 1D6 for each hit, adding their armour value.  Each score of six or more is a save.  All natural rolls of 1 are fails.
    


Victory conditions are at the discretion of players.

Name: Lorenzo il Magnifico: Houses of Renaissance
Description:
Description from the publisher:

In Lorenzo il Magnifico: Houses of Renaissance, each player now becomes the head of a powerful house of Renaissance, each of which has a strong special ability that only that player can use. Players choose the houses from the ten available at the beginning of the game through a special and fast auction. This expansion also introduces:


     48 new Development Cards and a fifth tower, where these cards are placed. These cards add to the game a lot of new powerful effects.
     20 new Leader Cards with a new leader mechanism.
     30 special tokens that player can take and use in combination with the new cards, and that add new way to collect resources and perform actions.
     The components to add a fifth player to the struggle for the power.

Name: Furious Ascent
Description:
Furious Ascent is a cooperative game for 2 to 4 players. The object of the game is for all players to progress as a team through four ascents to reach the mountain summit. If all players are healthy enough to reach the summit, the game is won. If any player becomes too injured to continue on during the game, it will result in an immediate loss.

Teammates play colored rope cards in the proper order to conquer four ascents, with each ascent becoming more difficult than the last. Each of the four camp cards has different requirements on how many rope cards and how many colors can be used to progress to the next camp.

If any player during their turn is unable to play the next card in the sequence, they must draw from the Event Deck. Events can penalize the individual player with various ailments, or the team as a whole with loss of progress in the ascent. If any player obtains too many ailments during the game, the entire team fails, and the game is lost. If all players reach the summit, the game is won!

Name: Axes and Allies
Description:
Axes and Allies is a simple dice game for 2-6 players.  One axe and 1D6 are required for each player.

During his turn a player rolls his dice.  The number obtained is the power of his axe for that turn only.  The player than has the choice between attacking another player or declaring an alliance.

If he chooses to attack, he selects a victim (he may not choose to attack an ally) and rolls his dice.  If the roll is less than the power of the axe the attack is successful and the player is eliminated.  If the roll is equal to or greater than the power of the axe the attack fails.

If he chooses to declare an alliance he may ally with any one other player.  The individual chosen has no choice in the matter.  Allied players may not attack each other.

If at any point a player rolls a one for power all players' past alliances are voided.  If a player is allied with all other players, that player's turn is limited to a power roll (to see if they roll a one).

The last player to execute a turn is considered the winner.

Name: Butlerian Jihad
Description:
A two player card game themed on The Butlerian Jihad in the Dune Universe as described by the Prequel Trilogy. After a thousand-year standoff, the War between the Free Human League of Nobles Worlds and the Intelligent Machine controlled Synchronized Worlds escalates.

One player is the Humans. The other player is the Machines. Each player has their own unique deck. Each deck has 6 suits. Each card has a force value and a special ability. Some special abilities require their ability to be activated, other abilities automatically take effect when the card is recruited or as a Free action discarded from the hand or in-play.

Each player starts the game with 3 Empire Tokens.

Each round has 6 Phases.

1.  Initiative Phase 
-   Players roll high on 1D6. High roll is the attacker. Low roll is the defender.

2.  Fate Phase
-   Each player draws 5 cards from the top of his deck.

3.  Strategy Phase
-   Each player may discard up to 2 cards and draw replacements.

4.  Battle Phase
-   Players take turns starting with the attacker. On his turn a player can either Recruit (put a card into play face up in front them), Activate (use the activation ability of a card in play if it has one) or Pass. 
-   If both players Pass, one after the other, the Phase ends. 
-   Once a player passes, he must continue to pass, unless his opponent causes one of his in-play cards to be discarded or eliminated. 
-   Normally, during the round, a player can only recruit a max of one card from each of the six suits. Some cards as their special ability allow you to recruit more than 1 card of a particular suit. 
-   A card can only be activated once per round.

5.  Resolution Phase
-   Add up the modified force values of all the cards in-play. The player with the highest score wins. If tied, players roll high on 1D6 to determine winner. 
-   The winner takes an Empire Token from the loser. 
-   The winner causes one target in-play card of his opponent to be discarded.

6.  End Phase
-   Each player can allow up to 9 of their in-play cards to remain in play. Excess cards must be discarded. 
-   Max hand size is 3 cards. Discard excess cards

The first player to control all 6 Empire Tokens wins the game.

Name: The Byzantines
Description:
